{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3555789,"name":"Justin Fischer","username":"justfishin99","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/a9adbd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T02:48:32.929Z","cooked":"

I’m trying to figure out how to have path planner bring us up to the reef, and then call a named command that will make the robot strafe left/right based on the crosshair/limelight configuration, and then be able to continue running in pathplanner.

I can get an instant command to cause it to auto align in teleop (basically using while true and while false to toggle), but I cannot get it to run the auto alignment command in auto. I debugged enough to see that it’s calling the command itself, but is never actually running the command to move.

I assume my issue is that pathplanner has control of the drivetrain and the command I am trying to schedule is not running as path planner is already using the subsystem, however, I am unsure how to fix that. I’ve tried using the path planner api to override the x and y headings, but that has not been successful either.

Latest code is here: GitHub - justfishin1999/frc4728-2025

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-13T02:49:43.843Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":125,"reads":203,"readers_count":202,"score":635.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495401,"topic_slug":"align-with-april-tag-in-auto-using-path-planner","display_username":"Justin Fischer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/justfishin1999/frc4728-2025/tree/main","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - justfishin1999/frc4728-2025","clicks":17}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62543,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/align-with-april-tag-in-auto-using-path-planner/495401/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3557017,"name":"Justin Fischer","username":"justfishin99","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/a9adbd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-14T15:33:07.614Z","cooked":"

For anyone who stumbles across this in the future - figured it out.

Basically you create a Named Command to register in Path Planner that will reference a drivetrain command. Command looks like this:

package frc.robot.commands;

import frc.robot.subsystems.CommandSwerveDrivetrain;
import frc.robot.Constants;
import frc.robot.LimelightHelpers;

import com.ctre.phoenix6.swerve.SwerveModule.DriveRequestType;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.swerve.SwerveRequest;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.swerve.SwerveRequest.RobotCentric;
import com.pathplanner.lib.controllers.PPHolonomicDriveController;

import edu.wpi.first.networktables.NetworkTableInstance;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.Command;

public class AutoAlign_Right extends Command {

private CommandSwerveDrivetrain drivetrain;
private RobotCentric limeDrive = new RobotCentric()
.withDriveRequestType(DriveRequestType.OpenLoopVoltage);
private double alignmentSpeed, m_xspeed;
private int m_pipeline;

public AutoAlign_Right(CommandSwerveDrivetrain drivetrain, double alignmentSpeed, int pipeline) {
this.drivetrain = drivetrain;
this.alignmentSpeed = alignmentSpeed;
this.m_pipeline = pipeline;
addRequirements(drivetrain);
}

@Override
public void initialize() {
NetworkTableInstance.getDefault().getTable(Constants.limelightConstants.leftLimelight).getEntry(“pipeline”).setDouble(m_pipeline);
}

@Override
public void execute() {
m_xspeed = NetworkTableInstance.getDefault().getTable(Constants.limelightConstants.leftLimelight).getEntry(“tx”).getDouble(Constants.limelightConstants.defaultValue)*alignmentSpeed;
drivetrain.setControl(limeDrive.withVelocityY(-m_xspeed).withVelocityX(0));
}

@Override
public boolean isFinished() {
return false;
}

@Override
public void end(boolean interrupted) {
}
}

You’d then create a NamedCommand to reference it in your Robot Container. Looks like this:

NamedCommands.registerCommand(“AutoAlign”,new AutoAlign_Right(drivetrain, 0.05, 0).withTimeout(1));

From there you can reference it in an auto in path planner. You’d need an event trigger for it to work in a path.

You should also look at 4915’s auto-align whitepaper. While they make a path on the fly to do their auto-aligning, it may still be useful to you in general.

This was incedibly helpful. How did you keep the robot from returning to it’s original postion on the path after running the auto align command?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-19T17:57:05.479Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":117,"readers_count":116,"score":28.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495401,"topic_slug":"align-with-april-tag-in-auto-using-path-planner","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74488,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/align-with-april-tag-in-auto-using-path-planner/495401/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3590839,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-13T16:10:46.587Z","cooked":"

You can do this by specifiying the end state of the alignment as the start state of the next path, rather than the end of the previous path. A really basic example:

  1. Pathplanner path drives to point A. This is a “Follow Path” in Pathplanner.
  2. Use a Named Command to align the robot with a given point, B.
  3. Finally, a new path in Pathplanner is ran that starts at point B.

Paths don’t necessarily have to start at the same spot the previous path ends. If you trust that your alignment code will actually do what it should, Pathplanner will be confused (and show a little ! icon in a yellow triangle in the UI), but it will allow that.

image2784×1664 290 KB

For example, this auto has two paths, StartF and FIntake (we label the scoring locations with letters, so F corresponds to a scoring location). StartF will end at a point a little outside of the reef, but FIntake begins at the actual aligned location. Pathplanner doesn’t understand that the autoalign code will move the robot, but it allows for this feature. Our Align F Named Command is responsible for moving the robot to the alignment target.

We actually just have each path start from where the last one was ‘supposed’ to end. We’ve had no issues with it so far (yet).
